results.content: This is an excellent course to take if you already have a solid understanding of React and how "class" and "functional" components are used. However, the use of Hooks is syntactically quite a bit different from the old "prop-drilling" style of building React apps, and I needed to watch each section of this course several  times before the logic began to make sense to me.  That's not a criticism of the presentation, it's more a cautionary note that the material itself can be a bit tricky.

results.content:
Overall good course, especially sections 2 to 4 which explains the essentials on React Hooks. 

Last section felt a bit rushed and I think this would be especially so with those who don't know or do too much with backend or APIs. 

My recommendation would be that instead of downloading api from git, the process would be shown or at least explained a bit more with tool like postman and mongodb. Showing how to deploy/host app to heroku, netlify or something similar would be valuable I think as well rather than tool chosen. 

I suppose this was purposely chosen to keep course short and concise and not merge away from react hooks. 

My final thoughts was React Hooks to replace Redux is so similar to Redux itself, that it left me wondering why? It simplifies things slightly maybe, but for any larger than `toy size` application I would probably choose Redux over React Hooks, especially with Redux Dev Tool extension being so handy.

results.content:
It was a good course but some concepts are not explained in well enough detail. The instructor assumes you will just "get it" on the first pass.

There are also libraries used (such as Axios) that are not given any explanation as to why they are being added or used over things like the fetch API.

Despite those small critiques the course was still very good at giving an overview of hooks and getting an advanced developer using them.

results.content: Overall, solid overview of implementing React hooks.  If you need a quick practical intro to hooks this will work.  Needs to be updated to reflect implementing cleanup in useEffect as well as keeping dep array honest.  Also Now has changed to Vercel. Felt like last section was rushed.  Got excited for creating custom hook but seemed like it could have been leveraged for all API HTTP methods. results.content:
I find courses that build an entire app utilizing all the concepts from the beginning (i.e. asynchronous CRUD capabilities) rather than building a simpler, modified version and then transitioning to the complete version are easier to follow. Otherwise two conflicting mental frameworks are introduced and blur the steps necessary to build an actual app.

So, I would suggest building a small versions (without a server) and then restarting and building an app with a server from scratch.

results.content:
This course is called react Hooks, but  just a few hooks are covered, it lacks one of the most important ones to avoid re-rendering (useCallback, useMemo) and it also doesn't talk about React.memo or techniques to migrate effectively class components to functional components.

Some classes are just videos showing how to write css classes into components attributes just to style the page. The final results are not even good!

This course is a waste of money and time. (sorry, but it is true, it is extremely incomplete)

response.content: We cover a hook (useReducer) that helps to replace Redux that allows us to prevent re-rendering with its built-in dispatch function. If you have used Hooks for any period of time, useCallback and useMemo are arguably the LEAST important hooks (and are basically the same). Not "just a few hooks are covered" all of the other hooks are. As for your second statement, there is an entire section on migrating traditionally stateful class components to function components, along with a side-by-side comparison of class and function components. Did you happen to miss that section? The third point--I made an *optional* video to better style the second application we made. I point that out in the list of lectures. And finally, point me to another course where you build complete applications using React Hooks like we do here. You won't find one. This course is an extensive and well-researched product and you're doing a disservice to students that would benefit from taking it to misrepresent the course in this manner. I seriously doubt you watched it.
response.content_html: We cover a hook (useReducer) that helps to replace Redux that allows us to prevent re-rendering with its built-in dispatch function. If you have used Hooks for any period of time, useCallback and useMemo are arguably the LEAST important hooks (and are basically the same). Not "just a few hooks are covered" all of the other hooks are. As for your second statement, there is an entire section on migrating traditionally stateful class components to function components, along with a side-by-side comparison of class and function components. Did you happen to miss that section? The third point--I made an *optional* video to better style the second application we made. I point that out in the list of lectures. And finally, point me to another course where you build complete applications using React Hooks like we do here. You won't find one. This course is an extensive and well-researched product and you're doing a disservice to students that would benefit from taking it to misrepresent the course in this manner. I seriously doubt you watched it.

results.content_html:
This course is called react Hooks, but just a few hooks are covered, it lacks one of the most important ones to avoid re-rendering (useCallback, useMemo) and it also doesn't talk about React.memo or techniques to migrate effectively class components to functional components.

Some classes are just videos showing how to write css classes into components attributes just to style the page. The final results are not even good!

This course is a waste of money and time. (sorry, but it is true, it is extremely incomplete)

I have learned much of the basics before watching this video, and have used hooks in my work at an intermediate to advanced level, but I am enjoying the presentation, and keen to see what details I have probably missed

However, the material does need to be updated to match the latest release.

The presenter skips over testing the code and in my opinion uses some bad practices, with logic and updates happening in the views rather than abstracted out. I think this is acceptable to focus on the subject, but it should be highlighted, probably constantly, that students should follow best practices in their own apps.
